head.supplied: Melbourne bot Garden ¶ 26./9/62 ¶ My dear Graf Decaisne ¶ ¶ I feel extremely obliged for your ¶ ¶ courteous & prompt attention to the few fragments of Australian Cucurbitaceae, sent by you a short ...

div.p: Bibliothèque de l'Institut de France, Paris.

To proof. Bot. names to check.
MS black edged; M's sister Bertha Doughty died 7 September 1861. Melbourne bot Garden

I feel extremely obliged for your courteous & prompt attention to the few fragments of Australian Cucurbitaceae, sent by you a short while ago & value the information from an authentic source vey much. Pray express to M. Naudin also my thanks. I have recently received good specimens of Lagenaria vulgaris from the Fitzroy River. I regret that the larger parcel with Cucurbitaceae, sent to you about 2 years ago was lost. It contained better specimens than the last one.
See M to J. Decaisne, 16 May 1859 and 25 December 1861. But when I travelled in tropical Australia
On the North Australian Exploring Expedition, 1855-6. I could not always collect perfect specimens & saw them often only in an imperfect state; moreover unfortunately a whole case with specimens (& in it many Cucurbitaceous ones) was spoiled in the voyage from Arnhems Land to Sydney. In Kew however of most of the cucurbitaceous plants some good specimens are extant, the main collection, as belonging to the British Government having been deposited there. Cucumis jucunda & C. picrocarpa I have watched for a long time in North Australia, where they are not rare. I have never seen any intermediate forms! C. jucunda has small fruits
always
of sweetish taste which in travelling we constantly used for food when available. C. picrocarpa has always larger fruit as bitter as C. Colocynthis. In what relation both stand to C. pubesoma [W.] can only be ascertained by reference to orginal specimens. Zehneria micrantha I have referred to Muckia (vide fragm. phyt. II, 180,)
we have this in App. C as: B59.11.01, 182.
as it has free anthers. It
sic.
fruits are always
much
larger than those of Muckia […]cataella, altho' occasionally ovate; the fruit of Muckia seabaella I found always beautifully
red (coccineus) that of Muckia micrantha is yellowish - green .
In comparing Ceylon specimens of Thichosanthes cucamerina with T. olida, I am inclined to regard them individual
I trust that the Cases pr Moravian will reach you in safety and that I shall be able to follow up these transmissions to your Museum regularly
